title: quietest-times-shop-asda-aldi-tesco-sainsburys
story: As lockdown continues to ease across the UK, analysis provided by Google visiting data has highlightedthebest times for shoppers to head out when less people are in stores.Heres a round-up from the top supermarket chains.AldiAldi stores are more likely to be quieter on weekdays, rather than on weekends.Those wanting to do a quick shop should avoid visiting their storiesat pm on Sundays, when the branches tend to be attheir busiest, with a wait time of up to  minutes expected.The quietest time to shop at Aldi tends to be before am and after pm on Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Thursdays.AsdaFor shoppers heading to their local Asda store - the busiest days are usually Mondays and Fridays.The data also revealed that shoppers should expect to spend up to  minutes waiting on Mondays, when heading there between am and pm.The quieter days to shop are on Tuesdays, Wednesdays Thursdays and Sundays.SainsburysThose planning on a tripto Sainsburys should head there on Wednesdays, which tend to be the quietest day to shop there.Elsewhere, the busiest days for customers are on Fridays and Saturdays - with a -minute wait time between am and pm on a Friday, and a wait of minutes between pm and pm on a Saturday.TescoIf youre a Tesco shopper, its best to avoid their Express,and Superstores on Monday afternoons.On the other end of the scale, those wanting to carry out their essential shop should head out before midday and after pm on weekdays - as those are the quietest times.Customers can expect to wait up to  minutes between the hours of pm and pm on Saturdays - which tends to be the busiest time of the week.MorrisonsFinally, for those who head to their nearest Morrisons supermarket - best to avoid visiting on Saturdays at noon, with an average wait of up to half an hour.Its also busy in Morrisons on a Friday from pm until pm.The quietest day to go is on a Wednesday.

title: twitter-trialling-new-read-retweet-feature
story: The new prompt, which will appearusers attempt to retweet an article posted by another user without first having clicked on it, is being trialled initially for Android users only.What have Twitter said about the change Twitter said: ldquoSharing an article can spark conversation, so you may want to read it before you tweet it.ldquoTo help promote informed discussion, wersquore testing a new prompt on Android ndash when you retweet an article that you havenrsquot opened on Twitter, we may askyoursquod like to open it first.The move comes amid continuing conversations about the spread of fake news on social media.Twitter product lead Kayvon Beykpour said: ldquoItrsquos easy for links articles to go viral on Twitter.ldquoThis can be powerful but sometimes dangerous, especiallypeople havenrsquot read the content theyrsquore spreading.ldquoThis feature ndash on Android for now ndash encourages people to read a linked article prior to retweeting it.Twitter has often received criticism for not doing enough to combat the spread of misinformation on its social media .Last month -it flagged two tweets from US President Donald Trump when he made unsubstantiated claims that postal voting would lead to widespread fraud.

title: chari-tea-fundraiser-take-place-weekend
story: Muirfield Riding Therapy, like a number of a charities across the country, has missed out on spring and summer fundraising due to the coronavirus.The group, based at West Fenton, still has ponies and horses to care for during the global pandemic.A spokeswoman for the group said: ldquoOn Sunday from .pm until .pm there will be a plant stall and our amazing cake stall outside the Mallard Hotel in Gullane.ldquoAll items will be priced so there will be no handing produce over.ldquoWe hope the queue will, of course, social distance.ldquoPlease do come and support us as our charity needs your wonderful support.

title: singers-tune-hospices-hope
story: Lorraine McBrearty, from Musselburgh, and Leanne Adams, of Dunbar, are both supporting Hospices for Hope with their separate renditions of the Leona Lewis song Footprints in the Sand.Their vocal performances ndashwhich they filmed and put online ndash promote the UK-based charity, founded by Graham Perolls OBE, which provides care for people who are terminally ill or suffer from a le threatening disease in Romania, Serbia, Moldova and Albania.Mr Perolls, CEO of Hospices for Hope, and his daughter Deborah sang Footprints in the Sand with the London Community Gospel Choir at the opening of a new hospice in Romaniarsquos capital, Bucharest.Regional manager Gordon MacIvor said the charity was trying to raise funds for a nurse at a ward at Serbiarsquos first purpose-built hospice centre.The ward is named after Elsie Inglis, the Scottish doctor and pioneering surgeon who served as Serbiarsquos chief medical officer during the First World War.Mr MacIvor explained: ldquoElsie is still celebrated in Serbia for all she did to help and was the first woman to ever receive The Order of the White Eagle.A number of singers ndash including Lorraine, , a dentist at Duncan Smith Dental Practice in Musselburgh, who lives on the townrsquos Bridge Street, and Leanne, of Dunbarrsquos Wilson Place, a -year-old mum-of-one who works at the Royal Bank of Scotland in Haddington ndash answered the charityrsquos social media call to sing a song in support of the cause and post it online.Lorraine, one of the first to take part, produced her own video of the song which already has received more than , views.Mr MacIvor said: ldquoThis really helps people to know who we are.ldquoI really didnrsquot know we had so much readily available, charitable talent in our community.ldquoI have been humbled by the people wanting to help. Lorraine has also suggested that they could maybe all get together and create a group song at one point, which I think is fantastic.It is also hoped to host a charity event to showcase the singers when the Covid- crisis is over.Leanne said: ldquoMusic is something that unites people everywhere, especially when we need it the most.ldquoIf we can help such an incredible cause and extremely brave people, then singing to raise awareness is the least I can do.ldquoThe song I have covered is Footprints in the Sand as I love the sentiment that fits the selfless work the hospice does to support people in need of love and support, especially during such a dficult time as this.ldquoThere are so many that need our help ndash any awareness and money we can raise will provide a leline to people who really need it.Lorraine, who is also a family worker at Northesk Church, Musselburgh, had also wowed people in Musselburgh and around the world with her weekly songs ndashfilmed and put online by her son Adam ndash following the Clap for Carers tributes which were held each Thursday.She said Hospices for Hope was ldquoan amazing charity and appealed to the public to help support a nurse at the Elsie Inglis ward.To view Lorrainersquos video go to her Facebook page www.facebook lorraine.mcbrearty and to see Leannersquos performance visit www.youtube channel UCC_LiafBXixVFHtfAtyQTo donate go to www.hospicesofhope appeal nurses-appeal-hospices-of-hope-scotland

title: cardboard-cops-slowing-drivers
story: Constables Colin Boyd and Charlie Duncan, Haddington and Lammermuir ward community officers, deployed the lsquopop uprsquo police officers in Humbie and East Saltoun last week.The cut-out officers, already in use in the Dunbar and East Linton ward, are intended to slow down motorists when travelling through towns and villages.A spokesman for Police Scotland said: ldquoLocal residents provided positive feedback in relation to the lsquopop uprsquo cops, stating that they appear to slow motorists down.ldquoBoth officers will also conduct static speed checks over the course of the next few weeks in ious identied locations in their ward area.

title: gala
story: Gala Queen Neve Campbell and Gala King Roby Gray, accompanied by piper Matt Sinclair, will walk round the village, waving their flags while observing Covid- pandemic social distancing rules.They will start at the local primary school at pm and cover most of Whitecraig.Local residents are being asked to stand safely at their gates to cheer on the royal party and mark the gala which has been cancelled this year due to the coronavirus crisis.They are also being urged to put up flags at their houses.

title: supermarket-supports-charity-meals
story: Scotmid Co-operative is backing the Pennypit Trust to provide food and essentials to those in need of support in Prestonpans.The Pennypit Trust improves health and wellbeing through sport, community development, nutrition, family engagement and volunteer development.During the Covid- pandemic, the trust has provided about , meals per week to Prestonpans families, the elderly and adults who are struggling.Scotmid has provided food vouchers to assist with ingredients for nutritious meals, as well as to donate to households who are struggling to buy fresh items.Kirsty Connell, Scotmid membership and community manager for the east of Scotland, said: ldquoWe are honoured to support the trust on its mission and provide help to those in need at this dficult time.The Pennypit Trust is predominantly relying on food donations to make up nutritious cooked meals, recipe bags and a basic essentials bag.Due to the high number of people who need support, stock of essential items has been in high demand and the trust is still receiving new referrals for people who need their help.Lorna Bellany, from the Pennypit Trust, was delighted with the donation.She said: ldquoWe have been overwhelmed by the kindness and generous donations we have received during this dficult time.ldquoThese vouchers from Scotmid will go a long way in helping us support families in the Prestonpans community.

title: butcher-hangs-apron-50-years
story: Colin Peat has served customers from the business on the townrsquos Court Street since he was just a teenager.On May , he shut up shop for the last time but not before a huge number of people visited Colin D Peat to wish him well in his retirement.He said: ldquoThey were really pleased that I have given all the years of service but, having been here for so many years, I have worked my time and I deserve a bit of retirement.ldquoI have never had anything like this before: the response to it has been unbelievable.ldquoThrough social media there are hundreds ndash Irsquom not sure how many but I know it is over  ndash of messages where they have given their wishes and comments.ldquoIn terms of gts and the lsquothank yousrsquo I have received over the last week, it has been absolutely overwhelming.ldquoThey have actually been queuing out on the pavement just to say their goodbyes to me on Friday and Saturday.The -year-old decided at the beginning of the year that he would bid farewell to the shop where he has worked since , alongside his dad, also called Colin.Starting out at just  years of age, Colin took over the running of the shop after his dad passed away in July .He said: ldquoI have always been one of those people that got up every morning and looked forward to coming to my work.ldquoI have done that all my le and it does not matter whether somebody coming in is spending pound or pound, I have always given them the same service.Among his customers was the late Clarissa Dickson Wright, who was famous as one half of the BBC TV show Two Fat Ladies, alongside Jenner Paterson.Clarissa, who died in , walked into the shop one day looking for him to supply the meat for her restaurant at Lennoxlove House, on the outskirts of the town.Colin, who was also a retained firefighter at Haddingtonrsquos fire station for more than  years, said: ldquoShe wanted to introduce herself and bring in her head chef the next day to supply all the food for her new restaurant, followed by supplying all the food for , people at a James Taylor concert at Lennoxlove Estate shortly afterwards.ldquoIt continued on as business and a friendship.The father-of-two was looking forward to spending more time with his children, Kevin, who lives at Gairloch, and Karin, who lives in Ipswich, as well as the garden at his Haddington home.Kevin Watt, of Kevin Watt Butchers, worked with Mr Peat for  years before setting up his own business on the townrsquos High Street six years ago.He thanked Mr Peat for passing on so much knowledge and said: ldquoCongratulations on your retirement.ldquoThanks for giving me the years of experience in the butchering trade and the opportunity.Councillor Tom Trotter, who represents the Haddington and Lammermuir ward, also wished Mr Peat well in his retirement.He said: ldquoI wish him all the best. He has been a good servant to the community for a number of years.ldquoHe has been there for as long as I can remember and fair play to him.ldquoI hope he has a long, successful and happy retirement.

title: understanding-scotlands-slavery-links-important-says-mp
story: MANY constituents have been in touch about the events unfolding in the United States and, indeed, there were even some local demonstrations about them.Itrsquos both frightening and tragic and Irsquove co-signed letters to the Government and supported motions seeking action.Racism is sadly deep-rooted in the USA, predating even Gfordrsquos famous son, John Witherspoon, signing the Declaration of Independence in .Compounding that is institutional racism within many law enforcement agencies and a gun culture thatrsquos lethal.As Justice Secretary, I met many US police officers. They were iniably pleasant but Irsquod hesitate to approach an officer there, let alone ask the time or directions.But racism afflicts every society and Scotlandrsquos no dferent. We need to ensure that there are robust laws and that those who espouse abhorrent views are challenged.Though the issues here may be less marked than south of the border, let alone the United States, they do exist and therefore action needs taken.Understanding Scotlandrsquos role in the slave trade would also be useful. Some grew fantastically wealthy as a result of it and the Scottish economy expanded consequently, evenwealth wasnrsquot shared equally here.But many participated at a lower level. Even our own revered Rabbie Burns penned lsquoAe Fond Kissrsquo to his beloved Clarinda as she prepared to depart for Jamaica to join her husband.It wasnrsquot just in Edinburghrsquos New Town or Glasgowrsquos Merchant City that the opulence and riches were invested. Large estates and houses everywhere, even in the Lothians, were paid for by slavery itself, slave labour and, perversely, compensation for ending it.Of course, le here was harsh for many, with serfdom in the coal mines only ending at the beginning of the th century. But they were still recognised as persons, whilst a slave wasnrsquot even regarded as that.An understanding of Scotlandrsquos links with slavery is important.

title: plans-lodged-outdoor-adventure-playground-dogs
story: Dog activity parks and sensory gardens could be created as part of the proposals for Spilmersford Mains Farm, to the east of the village.A -acre section of land, north of the A, could be transformed specially for manrsquos best friend.Business documents are included in the planning application, which is being weighed up by East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department.It reads: ldquoAfter y research in the dog industrywe have assessed this to be a viable business in this location.ldquoWhat we want to do is provide a quality product in a good location that we think addresses a need that isnrsquot currently well served locally.ldquoOur customers will be a mixture of professional dog walkers and dog trainers using the adventure fields for both exercise and training with their client base. We also expect to welcome the dog-owning general public who are seeking a private and secure space to let their dog off the lead whilst also benefiting from an enriching experience within the sensory and agility zones in each field.ldquoAfter opening, we envisage eventually moving to a membership based access system and have hopefully successfully built a community of like-minded users.ldquoAll owners and dogs will be met for a compulsory induction session, where certicates of vaccinationswill be required and recorded with reminders sent out when they expire.Gordon Hood, of The Hood Partnership, is behind the plans, which will offer a range of services.The proposals outline being able to privately hire one of the three adventure fields, with each session lasting  minutes.Socialisation sessions would also take place at the weekend initially and are aimed at owners looking to socialise their dogs off the lead, as well as the possibility of dog training sessions.The plans state: ldquoWill be staffed initially by Gordon Hoodwith the potential for further employment opportunities further down the line depending on the business growth.ldquoGordon has undergone training at Safe Pawswith Shirley MacMillan who has been in the dog industry since  and is widely respected as a leading dog trainer and government advisor on best working practises in the industry.Expert advice has also been taken in terms of the design of any adventure park.The document notes: ldquoAfter much research in this area we have settled on a similar design in each field with dog agility equipment prevalent to allow dogs to improve their sense of balance and improve their strength and fitness.ldquoEffectively designed much like a childrenrsquos adventure playground, the parks are designed to stimulate the dogs mentally and physically.ldquoThe sensory lsquosnfrsquo gardens are packed full of natural smells and textures that help reduce a dogrsquos stress and anxiety.ldquoThey will be enclosed within a wooden fence akin to the example below and feature a field shelter and picnic table for customers to relax and enjoy their surroundings while their dog plays.ldquoThe agility zone is full of balancing equipment and a range of s to allow dogs to climb, explore and use up some of their stored up energy.

title: valet-cleans-paramedics-cars-say-thank-you
story: Lewis Ward, , owner of Saltire Mobile Valeting, visited the Haddington depot, located behind the townrsquos Tesco on Lydgait, on May .Lewis says he is now known locally as ldquothe bus stop guy, after an article about him cleaning bus shelters around Tranent, Ormiston, Elphinstone and Macmerry appeared in the Courier a few weeks ago.Lewis visited the depot and started washing staff membersrsquo cars without warning.He said: ldquoI went down and asked someone where the car park was for staff cars and they said it was round the corner. So I went round, pulled all the things out of the van and started washing them.ldquoI think the manager then came out and asked what was going on and what I was doing, and I told her I was showing my appreciation and saying thank you for all of the hard work they do.ldquoShe said it was a really nice thing to do and askedI needed anything. When I was done she askedwe could take some photos and they would bring the ambulances over.Lewis has dubbed his recent gesture his own version of the pm Clap for Carers and his own way of showing his appreciation.The former Ross High School pupil said: ldquoIt took me a few weeks to get things sorted but was well worth the wait to see some very happy faces.ldquoIt felt so much more rewarding than the bus stops. I think it was getting to see the workers face to face and say thank you.ldquoIt is what they all deserve. All of the guys at the depot were fairly chuffed.ldquoI even got a couple of messages from some of the guys at the depot afterwards to say thank you.He added: ldquoItrsquos got a good response on social media from people.ldquoDoing it all has actually made me busier. That wasnrsquot the plan, though ndash I just did it off my own back and to say thank you.He cleaned nine cars in total, using the same method as that for the bus shelters covering the cars in snow foam, brushing it in and washing it off.All of the vehicles received the full treatment, including getting tyres polished, the car waxed and alloys cleaned.He has now reopened his business but is working half shts and cleaning the van after every car, with the van also getting a deep clean every weekend.

title: stony-snake-slithers-way-wallyford
story: The colourful, creative design is giving youngsters added fun when they venture out for exercise each day during lockdown.The Knight family ndash Jack, , twins Kayden and Kai, aged eight, and their sister five-year-old Lily ndash launched the project which involves placing painted stones to form Wally the snakersquos body.Their mum, Sam Wylie, , of Inchview Crescent, got the idea, via social media, from a similar project in Prestonpans.The children painted stones from the garden and placed them to start off the design on the ground near the local library and office at Wallyford Primary School in Futures Way.They are now hoping other youngsters will follow suit by adding their colourful stones to make the snake even bigger.Sam said: ldquoI thought it was a fun thing for children to do while they are out for a walk.ldquoMine get so excited to see how many other stones have been placed there.Mhairi Stretton, headteacher at Wallyford Primary School, tweeted: ldquoWas lovely to stop and look at all the stones left on Wally.ldquoChildrenrsquos names, school values, messages of love, kindness and hope.ldquoReopening the building means so much in so many ways. Team Wallyford.

title: east-lothian-council-monks-retreat-plans
story: Parts of Monkton House, on the outskirts of Musselburgh, date back to the th century and its current owners spent decades restoring the property.Now they have been given planning permission to turn it into self-catering accommodation which will be aimed at large family gatherings of up  people at a time.Among the work carried out by the owners is a stunning Chinese drawing room complete with dragon wall paintings and a ceiling fresco, and an expressionist-style bathroom suite.Planning permission has been granted for the main house and a detached cottage to be turned into guest accommodation by East Lothian Council planners.There were no objections from the public.And it raised no concerns with Historic Environment Scotland or council departments.Until the late th century,Monkton House was used as a safe house for monks at Newbattle Abbey before becoming a family home. A tower on the site dates back to the th century but the gardens are thought to have been established after it was a private residence in the th and th century.

title: letter-taking-childs-gnome-no-joke
story: In order to win the garden gnome, you had to guess the name.So my son guessed the name Tommy, after his grandad who died of cancer in .Imagine our delight when the school phoned us to say we had guessed the correct name and, since then, Tommy the garden gnome has taken pride of place in our garden.On Monday, June , some heartless person took it from our garden and our son was deeply upset, for sentimental reasons.Then, on Saturday, June , we received an envelope through our door with photographs of Tommy in ious locations and a letter saying we were to collect him from our local train station ndash but when we went up, nothing was there.By this time, our son was deeply upset that someone could be so cruel, so we took the reluctant step and got the police involved for the sake of our son.Then we woke up on Sunday morning, the next day, and discovered Tommy was back in our garden.Whoever did this should be ashamed of themselves as, whilst it might have been a joke to them, the gnome has sentimental value for us and we took it deadly seriously.Alan LoughBoroughdalesDunbar

title: community-council-elections-hold-year
story: Elections usually take place every four years but, amid the coronavirus pandemic, East Lothian Council has decided to postpone the elections until October .There are  community councils in the county, from Musselburgh and Inveresk, and Whitecraig in the west to Dunbar and East Lammermuir in the east.Returning officer Monica Patterson, who took the decision to postpone the elections, said: ldquoApart from the obvious practical reasons for postponement, we strongly believe it would be beneficial to have continuity of community council membership to support and guide the invaluable community resilience work during the recovery phase expected to extend into next year.ldquoI would like to take this opportunity to thank all of our community councils for their continued support and assistance theyrsquore providing in their local communities at this time.Meanwhile, North Berwick Community Council is seeking dedicated and hardworking iniduals from their area with time to spare to fill its two vacancies. For further information and to express an interest, email secretary@northberwickcommunity council.org

title: choir-sing-thanks-community-raise-up
story: during the global pandemic.East Linton Community Choir had been due to perform at the end of March.However, Covid- saw the concerts cancelled so, instead, the members created their own version of You Raise Me Up, previously performed bymusicians ranging from Josh Groban to Aled Jones and Westle.Lorraine Cormack, conductor of the choir, which has been running for  years, said: ldquoEarlier this year, in March, the choir were meant to perform attheir annual concerts but due to the lockdown they could not.ldquoObviously, they were disappointed, so I decided to offer them a challenge.ldquoI sent them music and asked them to learn their part in the song and then send me a recording of them singing it.ldquoThis was no mean feat because it probably involved new technology to them.ldquoI then mixed all the tracks together on my computer and came up with this final version.ldquoWhat inspired the choir to do this was to thank all the local shops, businesses, volunteers, friends and neighbours who have been supporting EastLinton throughout the coronavirus and, probably, will have to do so for some time tocome.ldquoWe hope you like this track, so... East Linton, thank you.The choir has more than  members who, before the coronavirus, met in East Linton Community Hall each Wednesday evening.In , the choir hosted a concert on the last weekend of March which saw such high demand for tickets that, since then, the group have addedmore performances to the annual concert.Lorraine, who set up the choir after moving to the village, was pleased with howthe finished version of their recorded song turned out.She told the Courier feedback had been positive and said: ldquoIt has been absolutely amazing.ldquoWe are quite a small, reliant wee village and the local Co-op went above and beyond what I am sure theywere asked to do.ldquoThey were delivering on foot to people that could not go out and all of us are so reliant on the local pharmacyand surgery.ldquoWe thought it was good to tell these people that we are very grateful.The video has been viewed more than , times online.To hear East Linton Lockdown Choirrsquos version of the song on YouTube, go to shorturl.at hkD

title: community-resilience-volunteers-aberlady-dirleton-north-berwick
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at fourof the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.AberladySINCE the middle of March, a squad of volunteers have offered assistance to people who have needed shopping and prescriptions collected, as well as dogs walked.But visitors have continued to flood into Aberlady after lockdown restrictions were eased.Ian Malcolm, from the community resilience team, said little had changed in the village from a community resilience point of view.However, he highlighted it was increasingly busy at weekends, with people visiting the village and the local nature reserve.Ian said there were also a number of people parking illegally.Anyone needing help collecting shopping or prescriptions, or any other assistance during the continued lockdown, should contact Ian on   or Sam Robertson on  .Further information is available online at www.facebook Aberlady-Resilience-DirletonVOLUNTEERS working to help people throughout Dirleton have been thanked.Dirleton Area Resilience Teamfinished off National Volunteer Week, which took place June -, thanking the team of volunteers.During the coronavirus lockdown, helpers have undertaken more than  activities, including dog walking, shopping and collections of prescriptions.David Tait, DART lead co-ordinator, said: ldquoSpecial events have included a surprise visit by the Easter Bunny, the distribution of craft packs to children within the Dirleton area and the introduction of lockdown treats from DART to residents every fortnight.ldquoWe have seen the development of the D-Art Gallery by junior DART, and teenagers undertaking the Saltire Award, who have been busy baking.ldquoThanks also to all the people behind the scenes ndash those who are tirelessly cooking and baking to ensure a ready supply of soups, crumbles and cakes for the larder the area co-ordinators the finance convenor the DART editor, who regularly produces our newsletter and has recently designed our new website and the DART craft group, who are busy making face coverings.However, the group is also looking to the future, with strategic forward planning on how to move ahead as lockdown eases.David told the Courier that the team were trying to plan for every eventuality ndash working in partnership with the Scottish Government, East Lothian Council, the local community council and other agencies.Together, they hope to ensure that support, resources and provisions are in place for the benefit of the community.David added: ldquoWe think it is clear that, even when lockdown allows further easing, there will be a need for further support within the community. We aim to have that support in place when it is required.DART community essentials larder will continue to be a critical asset for the community, with the support date pushed back to October.If anyone has any comments about DART or requirements for support, please get in contact by email to DART.Coordinators@outlook or visit the website at dirletonresilience.orgDunbarORGANISATIONS continue to come together to help people needing assistance in Dunbar.The townrsquos community council has been heavily involved in the community resilience efforts throughout Dunbar and West Barns.Meanwhile, Home-Start East Lothian has been working to ensure hot meals are sent out to those in need.A weekly report noted there continued to be ldquoa small increase in the demand, with the group now working with families to enable them to start cooking for themselves, by reducing meals and instead providing a midweek store cupboard bag, with recipes and ingredients.Home-Start East Lothian is also working alongside the Fareshare Hub in Port Seton to provide the majority of the food, with donations also being made from other groups, including Shikz Ltd, Prestonpans.Mungoswells Malt and Milling also donated flour, which Dunbar Community Bakery turned into  loves, so people received a fresh loaf along with margarine and teabags.Meanwhile, other services, including collecting shopping and prescriptions, as well as dog walking, have continued.The appeal for laptops and tablets is also ongoing.George Robertson, chairman of Dunbar and East Linton Area Partnership, said: ldquoThe appeal for redundant laptops and tablets is going well, with about  devices ready for new homes.ldquoThese are being offered to the schools and any not required by them will be offered to community groups and youth clubs.ldquoEach device requires a fair bit of work. Some need minor repairs or upgrades, some arrive without power supplies and replacements have to be ordered.ldquoA few are dead on arrival or cannot be repurposed and these are broken down for spare parts.ldquoAll are thoroughly cleaned and sterilised, and the entire contents of the hard drive are wiped before being reinstalled with Linux Mint operating system. Those without Bluetooth are being fitted with a Bluetooth dongle.ldquoAs a result, these machines are all given a new lease of le and are able to access Google Classroom and all other educational software.ldquoInternet access is either via wi-fi or,that is not available, by linking to a smartphone via Bluetooth.North BerwickNORTH Berwick Coastal Community Connectionswas set up by the North Berwick Health and Wellbeing Association last year.Tillie Baird and Deborah Ritchie, co-chairs of the North Berwick Coastal Health and Wellbeing Association, said a key part of the project had been a link with the team at North Berwick Health Centre to help people who were suffering from the poor health effects of social isolation.A year ago it appointed Carol Stobie as a project worker and, since then, she has connected nearly  local adults with local gatherings and activities, including the projectrsquos own Scone Cafeweekly drop-ins.During the Covid- crisis, Carol has kept members connected through telephone befriending and a monthly newsletter.On June , NBCCC will be holding its AGM and it is hoping to appoint co-chairpersons to share its leadership role, as well as a secretary, treasurer and task group convenors to lead on specic areas of work such as fundraising, befriending, and becoming a charity.Carol said Community Connections was also part of the North Berwick Community Emergency Resilience Plan.ldquoOur focus is on social and emotional support and we are supporting our volunteer connectors in offering a telephone befriending service to our clients during title: community-resilience-volunteers-humbie-east-west-saltoun-bolton-macmerry-gladsmuir-ormiston
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at title: scotlands-lockdown-easing-scottish-spca-advice-dog-owners-know
story: Before tighter measures were introduced, most dogs were likely suited to the routine of their owners ndash which included being left indoors while they went out for work.But since March, thousands more people in Scotland have been working from home.The immediate impact would, of course, prove to be popular with your four-legged friend ndash however animal experts are warning of the consequences once lockdown ends.Speaking to Radio Clyde News, Alan Grant from the Scottish SPCA said there will likely be ldquoteething problems for dogs as measures ease further and office working s.He told the radio station: ldquoDogs are much like us, any change to the routine or their day-to-day le is going to have an impact on them.ldquoWersquove all had to change and work from home and adapt our working protocols, which has been dficult for us at the beginning but wersquore now more used to it. Itrsquos the same for the dogs.ldquoDogs may have been a bit unsettled at the beginning with the owners being there but theyrsquove now adapted to that situation ndash and itrsquos now about adapting to going back to the old situation of the owner not being there, and thatrsquos where there will be a bit of teething problems for a lot of people at the beginning.The Scottish SPCA have urged owners to start with "micro" changes now- leaving their dogsfor a short period of time with something to keep them occupied.They also suggest investing in a camera to have a greater understanding of your dogs behaviour when you are not there.Mr Grant continued: "We want to start right now with very small changes, we call it stress inoculation. If we never leave our dogs, theyrsquore never going to get used to it."So we would leave them for micro amounts of time ndash but wersquod do a lot of stuff before we went to leaving them."Wersquod look at their day-to-day le and how can we make that le more enriching."Are they food motivated  If so, can we give them something that will take them five or ten minutes to eat, while we leave for five or ten minutes ndash then see how they are."Something  that is a great idea is to get a camera and see how your dog is actually behaving when you go out."That way yoursquoll know whether they go sleep for half an hour and then get up and start panting or is it immediately when we leave."Mr Grant told the radio stationit is "imporant" to know how your dog reacts to being left on its own.He continued: "If they are confident being left on their own for a short while, then we probably donrsquot need to deal with separation anxiety because they can cope being left."If that is the case, we just need to build up on that time that they are on their own."Something like getting a camera can be very much to your advantage so we know what we are dealing with ndash perhaps revealing that they can cope fine but just get bored, so we can enrich their le and give them other things to do so that they are not as bored when you go out."This likely means your dog suffers from seperation anxiety.Symptoms of this includeyour dog starts pacing and panting the moment you leave the door.In that case, Mr Grant says, you "would maybe need to look at some form of tailored programme for your particular dogthat is the case ndash but without knowing that itrsquos very hard to make that call."You can find our more information from the Scottish SPCA here.

title: vandals-target-historic-cross
story: The vandalism, thought to have happened on Saturday night, was condemned by Councillor Stuart Currie who received messages from constituents about the incident the following day.He said: "This act of vandalism is an utter disgrace. There are so many people working hard to make our town better and then idiots come along looking for any excuse to try and damage a local landmark."I was contacted on Sunday and got in touch with council officers who are taking action to remove the graffiti whilst ensuring the stone is not damaged. I very much hope that the CCTV has captured those responsible and they are punished accordingly."A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: ldquoUnfortunately there was some graffiti on the Mercat Cross in Musselburgh which has now been cleaned off by the council. This is a criminal offence and we work with police and partner agencies to trace and prosecute anyone responsible for this type of crime where possible.The th century Mercat Cross, where markets were traditionally held and proclamations made, is situated near the Old Town Hall in the High Street.It stands on the site of the original medieval cross and, from a square pedestal, three steps rise to a Tuscan shaft of the late th century, supporting a lion and the burgh arms.The monument was focal point for proclamations as part of the turf cutting ceremony during the  Riding of the Marches which takes place in Musselburgh every  years.Police Scotland said it had no reports of the vandalism, which is not thought to have any links to any national cause or campaign such as Black Lives Matter.

title: face-masks-wear-one-properly-stop-glasses-steaming
story: Some form of facial protection must be worn for commuters to be able to travel on public trains and buses as of today , with the law to be enforced by transport operators and British Transport police ldquo necessary.Travellers can be fined and refused travelthey do not comply with the law.Very young children, disabled people and those who have breathing dficulties are exempt from the rules, but all other public transport users must comply fromJune .At the time of publication - similar rules regarding face masks and public transport have not been implemented across Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.But which types of face coverings are acceptable, and how do you wear them properly How do I wear a face mask properly The UK government has advised that scarves, or homemade cotton coverings, that cover the nose and mouth, and other bought masks that are not the same as those used by the health service are fine to wear.Surgical masks should be kept for use by health professionals.Officials have said that people can make a face covering at home, but added it is key to ensure it covers your nose and mouth.Government guidance states that a cloth face covering should cover your mouth and nose while allowing you to breathe comfortably. This can be as simple as a scarf or bandana that ties behind the head.Before putting it on, you should wash your hands or use hand sanitiser and do the same after removing it.Avoid touching your eyes, nose, or mouth at all times and store any used face coverings in a plastic bag until you have an opportunity to wash them.Do not touch the front of the face covering, or the part of the face covering that has been in contact with your mouth and nose.Once removed, make sure you clean any surfaces the face covering has touched and wash the covering regularly. The covering can be washed with other laundry, using your normal detergent.When wearing a face covering, take care to tuck away any loose ends.How do I stop my glasses from steaming up If you wear glasses, wearing a face mask at the same time can cause the lenses to steam up, making it dficult to see properly.But the common problem has an easy solution, thanks to advice from doctors in the medical journal Annals of the Royal College of Surgeons of England.To prevent the issue, doctors advise washing your glasses with soapy water before putting the mask on, and rinsing them under warm water.Then, gently dry off the lenses with a clean towel or cloth before putting them back on.Washing the lenses with soapy water leaves behind a ldquothin surfactant film that reduces misting on the lenses, meaning they now shouldnrsquot steam up when a face mask is worn.Should face coverings be worn where The current government advice states that face coverings should be worn in enclosed spaces, which includes some shops and public transport.At the moment, people are not being told to wear them outdoors, while exercising, or in schools or offices.Several airlines, including easyJet and Ryanair, have introduced a requirement for passengers to wear face masks on board.However, the government believes that face masks should be reserved for people who need them to protect against risks in their workplace, such as health and care workers.

title: Opinion  Rosemary Goring  One Glasgow boy ran to tell the farmer    39 they coos are eating a    your grass  39
story: With falling temperatures, the village moved back indoors. Yoursquod scarcely know that there has been any lting of lockdown. One neighbour says her grandmother scoffs at the idea that the coronavirus crisis is like the last war, when she was a child in a nearby town. Although they were often hungry, they had complete freedom. Even when the air raid siren went, and they had to e into shelters, they did not feel the all-pervasive threat of today.Nor, unless they were extremely remote or unlucky, were people shut off from each other. We talk a lot about the power of modern technology to keep us connected, but in those times, whether you were in a village or a city, there was daily contact with other folk, evenyou lived alone. People wouldnrsquot have felt the need for video calls when they could nip out of theirdoor and visit whoever they liked nearby. The Blitz spirit is not entirely a myth, but the circumstances in which it thrived were very dferent from this pandemic.My mother lived in London and, in , like countless city children, was evacuated to the country. She was luckier than many, being sent not to strangers but to an aunt, who lived in Herefordshire, near the Welsh border. There was no running water, light was by paraffin lamp, her uncle was an irascible war veteran, and her aunt would often retreat to bed for days, finding the extra responsibility rather too much. But for an -year-old, collecting eggs from under hens, sauntering up the lane for still-warm jugs of milk from the farm, and seeing a night-time sky lit by stars was a revelation. From then on, she counted the days until she could leave London forever.Not all evacuees felt the same way. Encountering beetles and bugs for the first time was hard enough, but herds of cows with a bull among them must have been pretty alarming. One boy, who had never previously left the Gallowgate, ran to tell the farmer that ldquothey coos are eating arsquo your grass. Another Glaswegian, taken into a Perthshire home, escaped onto the roof when they ran him a bath. He thought they were trying to drown him.Recalling that period, my mother spoke of country folksrsquo shock at the poverty of inner city children, who had come from slums. Those who organised the mass evacuation were appalled to discover that, when asked to provide each child with a change of clothing, a toothbrush and enough food for a dayrsquos journey, a lot of families were unable to do so. It was a sobering eye-opener. Rural hardship was re, but it did not compare to the scale of urban deprivation: barefoot youngsters with rickets, scurvy, ringworm, or so underfed they were the colour of lard.Itrsquos hard to imagine what it must have felt like to be dropped into a world of fields and trees and pitch black nights, when you were used to well-lit canyons of concrete and stone or to find yourself alone in a bed, when usually therersquod be siblings on all sides, keeping you warm, and your parents only a step away. Some children were so miserable, they had to be sent home. For others, like my mother, it sparked a lelong love of the countryside.Not that she idealised her auntrsquos way of le. Some aspects of it were, for a Londoner, like stepping back in time. Nor, in the s, was there any glamorising of country le. It was often equated with backward attitudes and ignorance. If anything, most villagers dreamed of escaping to the city, or at least the suburbs, and a clean, warm house with all mod-cons.Irsquove been reading Dirk Bogardersquos memoir, Great Meadow, in which he recalls his childhood in the Sussex Downs, from the age of six. Between  and , he spent weekends and long spells of holiday in what his affluent parents called a cottage, but photos show as a substantial house. Later he was packed off to Glasgow, which he loathed, but thatrsquos another story. In Great Meadow, he and his little sister were looked after by a nanny, while his actress mother swanned around in a kimono, and his father raced up and down to London where he was on The Timesrsquos picture desk. Bogarde often mentions the healthiness of the country, compared to London, where public transport was frowned on, because of the risk of germs. This was a legacy, perhaps, of the Spanish flu.Bogarde loved everything about the cottage, but the most noteworthy feature was the outside lavatory. Every Friday he had to dig a hole in the garden and, under cover of dusk, empty the privy bucket into it. His great fear was of tripping, because sanitation was basic. Theyrsquod have a weekly bath, filled by their nanny, but his parents preferred going to the nearest pub for their ablutions.Years ago I visited friends in rural Perthshire who had an outside toilet. I rather liked it: it was made of wood, and smelled of sawdust. Unlike the shed at the bottom of many cottage gardens, one wall was open, so the view was lovely, even in the snow. You didnrsquot have to crunch over snails in the dark to reach it ndash bedrooms came with chamberpots ndash and as a guest there was no fear of ever being asked to empty it. To watch him on screen, yoursquod never think Bogarde was the man to cope with such a noisome task. If for any reason it suddenly becomes a necessary chore in our cottage, Irsquoll be with the Gallowgate evacuees, heading straight back to the flushing loos of the Merchant City.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. title: Opinion  Iain Macwhirter   Bagpuss Boris  followed the wrong science
story: The PM is losing supporters left and right. The Government is rudderless, drting making contradictory decisions or no decisions at all.Boris Johnson had nothing sensible to say about the Black Lives Matter demos which drove a coach and horses through the lockdown. He could either have endorsed the protests as legitimate on moral grounds, or called on the police to enforce the law. He did neither until forced to. Leadership was lacking.The belated introduction of a -day quarantine for travellers to Britain seems like a self-destructive exercise in closing the door after the viral horse has bolted. His Government is cancelling border checks on the , lorries that enter the UK every day, while also saying that the Brexit transition period will not be extended.:Nicola Sturgeon: Boris Johnson putting political interests ahead of the public interestJohnson is accused of allowing children in England to go to theme parks but not to schools, leading to further problems for students from disadvantaged backgrounds. The two-metre rule is causing massive problems as the economy tanks, yet the medical evidence for its effectiveness is contradictory.But the most serious accusation made last week against Boris Johnson was that he was asleep at the wheel in early March, and that his dilatory behaviour led to the deaths of tens of thousands of people.The claim was made by the former SAGE member, Professor Neil Ferguson .ldquoHad we introduced lockdown a week earlier, the Imperial College epidemiologist told MPs last week, ldquowersquod have reduced the final death toll by at least half.In other words,the UK Government had closed the schools and shops on March  instead of March , the official death toll might have been , instead of ,. This retrospectively validates Fergusonrsquos own forecast back in March that, on his model, lockdown should have kept the death toll to around ,.I think most now accept that the UK did just about everything wrong in its response to Covid-. We didnrsquot close the borders, didnrsquot protect care homes, abandoned testing and locked down too late. The question is: who is to blame for all this The editor of The Lancet, Richard Horton, in ldquoThe Covid Catastrophe which is to be published this week, names the guilty man: Boris Johnson. He failed to attend crucial meetings of COBRA, the Cabinet crisis committee, failed to listen to scientists, and thought the country should ldquotake it on the chin in order to protect the economy.But it was not just the PM who delayed lockdown by one week. This was also the policy of the Scottish Government.I happened to be in the Scottish parliament on March , the day that Leo Varadkar announced the closure of schools and universities in Ireland. At First Ministerrsquos Questions, Nicola Sturgeon explained why she was not following suit. She was, she insisted, ldquofollowing the science.School children sent home were likely to take the disease into their communities and to older people, ldquowhich might be a greater risk in terms of spread of infection than their being in school. She also said that parents would have to stay at home to look after them and this would denude staff for essential services like the NHS.:London Protests: More than  arrested as Boris Johnson condemns far-right protests as lsquoracist thuggeryrsquoIt all seemed sensible at the time. The national clinical director, Jason Leitch, was all over the media saying that the vast majority of us were going to get the virus anyway, because there was no vaccine, and that we had to ldquoprotect the vulnerable as it ldquoworked its way through the population.The release of SAGE minutes two weeks ago confirms that the scientic advisers were at best cool about lockdown. They may not have been in thrall to heartless herd immunity, but they did believe that trying to suppress the virus would be counterproductive.On March , the minutes say "SAGE was unanimous that measures seeking to completely suppress the spread of Covid- will cause a second peak.It added that it was ldquoa near certainty that countries such as China, where heavy suppression is under way, will experience a second peak once measures are relaxed.The scientic consensus was that eradication of the disease was not possible because it would spread until herd immunity ndash % of the population ndash finally burned the virus out. But Jacinda Ardern, the prime minister of New Zealand, took a dferent view. She closed the borders immediately cases appeared and kept them closed, and imposed a severe lockdown internally and suppressed the virus until it disappeared. Last week she declared victory over Covid ."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Coronavirus in numbers: UK death toll at ,","description": "Coronavirus in numbers: UK death toll at ,","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media gHqFBAP poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests gHqFBAP.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": Only time will tell whether SAGE was right. There may indeed be a second wave and New Zealand will have very little immunity to it. Borders cannot be kept closed forever. However, the minutes seem to confirm that, as Professor Lawrence Freedman argued in the New Statesman, ldquothe Government was largely following SAGErsquos advice.Some have claimed that Nicola Sturgeon wanted to follow dferent advice and was overruled by Westminster. That isnrsquot the case. The First Minister was following the same scientic advice as Westminster, and made clear she did not believe lockdown was yet necessary or desirable on March .Itrsquos hard to believe that a weekrsquos delay could have led to , deaths, as many as on the first day of the Battle of the Somme. Scientists will debate this for years.Indeed, analysts in Bristol, led by the mathematical modeller Professor Simon Wood, now claim now that the disease peaked before lockdown was introduced, suggesting that SAGE was right.SAGE had always argued, as the minutes show, that the best way to contain the spread was hand washing, social distancing, and protecting the old and vulnerable. The UK Government was only persuaded of lockdown by Neil Fergusonrsquos infamous forecast, on March , that without it , would die.The one thing we have learned from coronavirus is that science is not a monolith and that scientists disagree as much as politicians. All of which makes little dference to the state of the PMrsquos popularity, which dropped dramatically during Cummingsgate and has not recovered.Tory commentators are whispering that Johnson has lost it, doesnrsquot look well. Has he fully recovered from Covid- himself  He nearly died, after all.Itrsquos dficult to tell with Boris Johnson because he never seems particularly in command. For an intelligent man, he is remarkably inarticulate. He ldquoums and ldquoahs his way through Prime Ministerrsquos Questions ashe is making it up as he goes along. The suspicion is that he is, and that he relied too much on Dominic Cummings to do the thinking for him.Before he became Prime Minister, Johnson had a reputation for being lazy and shallow. Three years ago, his Tory colleague and rival Michael Gove said that ldquoBoris cannot provide the leadership or build the team for the task ahead. Gove recanted ndash but it could be he was right all along.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald

title: Opinion  Marianne Taylor  George Square needs to be completely overhauled - here   s why
story: The new station completely transforms the look and feel of this part of town. What a shame, then, about the second thing I couldnrsquot help noticing: how drab and disappointing George Square remains.Granted, the grim sight of loyalist protesters wrapped in Union flags ldquoprotecting the statues and Cenotaph didnrsquot help. But even without their isive presence the cityrsquos historic square is a let-down, visually, socially and culturally, a frustrating waste of urban space that could and should be far better utilised.Where other European squares create buzz and atmosphere with year-round arts, culture, food and shopping attracting locals and visitors, George Square is dreary and uninspiring: a few trees, some benches and a clutch of dull, predictable th-century statues ndash ldquogreat men and Queen Victoria ndash that few feel any kinship with. The only part of the square that has any real purpose and meaning is the Cenotaph.The idea that George Square is in serious need of a makeover is nothing new, of course, and there have been ious  dawns and broken promises over the years, not least the outrageous fiasco of  ndash remember that  ndash which wasted huge amounts of public money and goodwill alike. But the two defining events of  - coronavirus and the Black Lives Matter protests -offer Glasgow the best opportunity in a generation to finally get this right and transform George Square into the vibrant civic centre Glaswegians deserve.Letrsquos start with the pandemic, which will continue to damage the economic and social pull of town and city centres. As lockdown restrictions are gradually lted we will grasp a new reality ndash fewer shops, restaurants, bars and cultural attractions than before, with those that do re-open unable to work at full capacity for now. Answers to the sort of questions around attracting people to city centres that were already stumping businesses, planners and local authorities even before coronavirus hit have become all the more pressing.Thatrsquos where a proper revamp of George Square comes in, a key step forward in boosting Glasgowrsquos economy and cultural capital in the wake of the pandemic. What should the square contain  That would be for citizens to decide, but herersquos a few quick ideas that presume an eventual end to social distancing: an ampitheatre for live music, theatre and comedy, proper seating, pop-up pods for community groups, a food and craft market, arts and exhibition space, murals, a garden and childrenrsquos play area.As for the fate of the statues, again, it would be for the people to decide whether they still have a place in this new urban realm. Not that we would want to forget our past, of course. But surely we can find new and more creative ways to confront, commemorate and celebrate it, taking in voices that were previously ignored ndash women, ethnic minorities, working class people, gay people, the disabled ndash reflecting the ersity of our city as it is now.Rather than an expensive international competition for designs ndash letrsquos learn from  ndash a three-month public consultation could be held, and a  of local architects, planners, artists, businesspeople and community groups convened to create perhaps three dferent plans, which would then be voted on by the people of Glasgow. Granted, such an ambitious revamp wouldnrsquot be easy to fund in the dficult years ahead, but with a crucial economic and culturalat stake, it should be prioritised. Surely a mixture of public, private and philanthropic funding could be sourced Glasgow City Council has already started the conversation that could make all this happen, by bringing forward the pedestrianisation of George Square and suspending a third of city centre parking bays to make room for walkers and cyclists.I would urge council leader Susan Aitken and her team to think bigger. A commitment to redesign George Square would offer an exciting, positive and inclusive focus for Glaswegians in the tough months ahead. The end result could be what Glasgow has been crying out for for a generation: a proud and modern civic centrepiece that is worthy of our great city, a place that excites, entertains, and educates, that makes us feel part of something bigger. Wersquove never needed it more.All columnists are free to express their opinions. They donrsquot necessarily represent the view of The Herald.

title: alarm-bells-scotlands-unemployment-rate-becomes-highest-uk-nations
story: Unemployment in Scotland is now running at .%, compared with a UK rate of .%, which business leaders say "should set alarm bells ringing".New figures from the Office of National Statistics show that the unemployment rate in England, Wales and Northern Ireland is .%, % and .% respectively.Unemployment in Scotlandrose by , to , between February and April as lockdown hit the labour market.Scotlands unemployment rate is now at its highest level forover three years.: UK billionaires see personal wealth grow by poundbn during pandemic lockdownEconomy Secretary Fiona Hyslop said the countrys reliance on the tourism industry was the main reason behind the rise in the Scottish unemployment rate."The scale of whats coming down the track will be far, far more than weve seen here and that is why the scale of the response has to equal that challenge," she said.Citiizens Advice Scotland warned that the new figures "may be the tip of the iceberg" to the state of the economy later in the year as the furlough scheme winds down and industries face reduced demand.CASs social justice spokesman Mhoraig Green said: ldquoPeople who find they have no job toto after furlough will be entering a dficult jobs market.ldquoItrsquos essential both the Scottish and UK governments look at ways to grow our economy in a way that creates fair paying, secure work.ldquoThatrsquos why CAS has called for more investment in energy efficient housing as a measure that could create jobs, as well as making state support for business contingent on fair work practices.ldquoThe whole UK may be facing an economic storm in the months to come. Itrsquos vital that the most vulnerable arenrsquot swept into deeper poverty as a result.Andrew McRae, FSBrsquos Scotland policy chairman, said: ldquoTodayrsquos figures should set alarm bells ringing in the corridors of power. Thatrsquos because they show unemployment rising even with support measures such as the furloughing scheme in place.ldquoTo ensure that the worst predictions for joblessness in Scotland donrsquot come to pass, wersquoll need governments in Edinburgh and London to help local firms get back to business and create jobs. The government must prevent a situation where measures to protect jobs are withdrawn but workers, consumers and firms still face lockdown conditions.ldquoAfter the last crash, nine in ten unemployed people that re-joined the workforce did so via a small business or though self-employment. In addition wersquore urging the UK Government lower the cost of employment by reducing employerrsquos national insurance contributions.Business, Fair Work and Skills ministerJamie Hepburn said the figures"show clearly the scale of the challenge" facing Scotland as a result of the coronavirus pandemic.He added: "I know that many people will be feeling a deep sense of anxiety about their livelihoods. Keeping people in work while supporting those who have lost their jobs will continue to be at the heart of our thinking as we carefully reopen the economy."Mr Hepburn also urged the UK government to ensure its support schemes reflected what was needed in Scotland."Failure to do so will put the economy at a competitive disadvantage in recovering from this crisis, and could result in additional job losses. We must not allow that to happen," he added.Across the UK, thenumber of workers on UK payrolls dropped by more than , between March and May, official figures suggest.Meanwhile, the number of people claiming work-related benefits - which includes the unemployed - was up % to . million.The early estimates reflect the impact of around six weeks of lockdown in which large parts of the UK were shut.

title: wetherspoons-provide-update-reopening-pubs-scotland
story: The popular pub chain is awaiting official instruction from the Scottish Government before reopening but will look to employ socially distancing measures.Providing an update to The Herald aspokesman for the company said: ldquoWe are as keen as all other pub operators to open our pubs and are awaiting official news from the Scottish government.ldquoWe will wait with interest to see when pubs will be allowed to reopen across Scotland.ldquoOur aim is to have all of our pubs in Scotland open immediately they are allowed to do so.Social distancing measures will result in the employment of two full-time staff per pub, slightly more for bigger pubs, who will regularly clean surfaces and touchpoints throughout the pubs.The company will open its  pubs in Scotland as well as the other  across the UK and Republic of Ireland when it has the official go-ahead from the relevant governments.:New Wetherspoons pub to open in historic Glasgow tearoomUnder their plans, all of its pubs will have screens at the till point andscreens willcreate seating areas where it is not possible to separate the tables to the social distancing requirement.Wetherspoon will provide gloves, masks and protective eyewear to employees who can elect whether to wear them or not, subject to government guidelines.There will be an average ten hand sanitiser dispensers around the pub, including at the entrance for customers and staff to use.Every employee will need to complete and sign a daily health assessment questionnaire to confirm that they are fit to work. This will include having their temperature taken using a digitalthermometer.As part of their social distancing policy,staff will monitor the pub at all times in order to maintainstandards with amember of staff on the door at peak times.Where possible, the pubs will also use one entrance with a separate exit door with entry and exit points marked out by floor stickers and or barriers. Clear printed information providing guidance to customers will also be visible upon entry.Each pub will have a member of staff working full timeto sanitise all the contact points during opening hours.These will include door handles, allergen information screens, card payment machines and handrails.Customers will be asked to use the Wetherspoon order and pay app, wherever possible, or pay at the bar using a credit debit card and contactless, although cash will be accepted.Staff will hand over all drinks holding the base of the glass and when ordered by the app they will be delivered to the table on a tray and placed on the table using the base of the glass.:Full list of JD Wetherspoon pubs set to close in ScotlandFood will be delivered to the table by a member of floor staff.The pubs will also offer a slightly reduced menu and will provide sachets rather than their usual condiment bottles.They will be open their usual opening hours and all staff will receive a full briefing and training on the new way of running the pubs.Wetherspoon chief executive John Hutson said: ldquoAt present, the government have not confirmed any reopening date for pubs.ldquoHowever, it is important that we are prepared for any announcement.ldquoWe have spent a number of weeks consulting with staff who work in our pubs, as well as area managers in order to draw up our plans.ldquoWe have received more than , suggestions from our staff.ldquoThe safety of our staff and customers is paramount.

title: fabiani-tories-cant-trusted-jobs-scottish-dfid-site
story: Labour, SNP and the Lib Dems have all called for the Conservative government to ensure  jobs at DfIDs headquarters in East Kilbride be saved following the announcement that the department will be merged with the Foreign Office.Although Downing Street has said no compulsory redundancies will be made, and that the site will remain with employees from the newly-formed Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office.SNP MSP for East Kilbride Linda Fabiani said the move meant her constituents faced an "uncertain future".She explained: ldquoYou simply canrsquot trust the Tories. In the midst of an economic crisis Boris Johnson has put the future of hundreds of Scottish jobs in doubt.ldquoTodayrsquos announcement is a real blow to the local community here in East Kilbride ndash especially in the current circumstances we all find ourselves in.ldquoDespite assurances, local workers in my constituency could now face an uncertain future.ldquoI will fight tooth and nail with my SNP colleagues at Westminster to keep these jobs in our community.Wendy Chamberlain, Liberal Democrat MP for North East Fe and the partys international development spokeswoman said the department measure was "cruel and backwards" adding: "UK aid does huge good around the world and this will undoubtedly damage it.ldquoDissolving the department could also have serious repercussions at home. Hundreds of employees and their families in the East Kilbride area will be left worried about the security or location of their jobs.ldquoThese jobs must stay put. We cannot afford to lose specialist expertise or put peoplersquos jobs in jeopardy in the midst of a pandemic.Ian Murray, Scotlands only Labour MP also urged Boris Johnson to protect the jobs.He said: "This is a wrong-headed move from a Prime Minister who is out of his depth.ldquoLabour created the Department for International Development and provided global leadership that ensured Britain was a moral force for good in the world.ldquoAbolishing this department which has done so much to tackle poverty and injustice would be a deeply retrograde step at any time, let alone at a time when global cooperation is needed more than ever.ldquoAs part of the UK, Scotland plays a vital role in the fight against global poverty through the work led by DfID staff in East Kilbride.ldquoIf this ill-judged merger goes ahead, it is vital the jobs in East Kilbride are fully protected.

title: businesses invited to join online meeting
story: This coming Monday, June , at .pm, businesses from across the Highlands  Islands are invited to take part in an hour-long online Federation of Small Business QA meeting with Fergus Ewing MSP, the Scottish Government’s cabinet secretary for rural economy and tourism.FSB research shows that the Highlands  Islands and Argyll’s dependence on its visitor economy – tourism  hospitality – means that lockdown has left this already fragile region more vulnerable economically than the rest of Scotland. Unsurprisingly, as time passes so businesses from across the region are increasingly seeking clarity on a wide range of issues vital to their survival.With Phase  of the unlocking process due shortly, the FSB believes that this is the perfect time for smaller businesses to question Mr Ewing on what the Scottish Government is doing to support businesses over the next year.The FSB’s Highlands  Islands Area Leader and director of the Kylesku Hotel, Tanja Lister, said: “We know how anxious businesses are becoming about their abilities to survive in this new world and, given that the virus is unpredictable, they clearly want as much clarity as possible so that they can plan their survival strategies once unlocking takes place.“In particular, they want to know when and how unlocking will take place, what they must do to comply with distancing protocols, how local communities will be persuaded that the time is right to unlock, and the nature of the Government-backed business support that will be put in place to carry the regional economy though to next Easter and beyond.“Nobody should think that businesses can go from nought to  in a few days – it will take a long time for them to recover, and many will need ongoing support from governments, public agencies, other businesses and, very importantly, the general public, for many months to come.“We know how heavily engaged Mr Ewing is in his vital role and we are delighted that he is giving up his time to take questions on Monday. This is the perfect time for him to meet Highlands  Islands businesses and we are looking forward to a very productive hour with him.”Questions must be submitted in advance and we will ask as many as we can in the allotted time, say the organisers. Participants can also submit comments during the meeting using Zoom’s ‘Chat’ .The event is free and open to all businesses. title: covid 19 safety measures implemented at kirkwall airport
story: New safety measures have been introduced at Kirkwall Airport as preparations ramp up for the gradual resumption of flights to and from Orkney.Wearing face coverings, hand sanitiser and strict adherence to social distancing are some of the requirements for all airport users as airlines begin a measured reintroduction of scheduled flights.Airlines have indicated they will look to begin a carefully planned introduction of non-international services to airports operated by Highlands and Islands Airports Ltdin the near future.HIAL airports have remained open to essential, leline services and emergency flights throughout the COVID- crisis, with key personnel on duty to ensure operations have been maintained during the lockdown.The airports will continue to rigorously follow Health Protection Scotland and European Aviation Safety Agency guidelines.Staff will wear more personal protective equipment than normal, including face masks and gloves where required, and screens have been installed.Physical distancing measures are in place with sanitiser stations in key locations throughout airports and regular deep cleaning is being carried out.Passengers will be required to wear face coverings before entering airport terminals and must keep them in place until their journeys are completed.Passengers are advised to arrive with their own face coverings, although a limited number may be available at airports, this cannot be guaranteed. Not wearing a face covering may mean passengers will not be able to travel.Due to social distancing requirements, the numbers of passengers within the terminal building will be limited and only travelling passengers will be allowed in the terminal. Special assistance support is still available for those who require it.All passengers will be welcomed by a member of the HIAL team on arrival who will help guide them through the new procedures.Based on the latest advice from the Scottish Government and Health Protection Scotland temperature checks are not currently required.Managing director Inglis Lyon, said: “My colleagues have worked extremely hard to offer a safer environment for passengers at our airports and we will continue to rely on the understanding and cooperation of travellers to follow our new procedures to make their experience as smooth as possible, given the current restrictions.“We are pleased that we are now able to focus on a safe and gradual resumption of air travel, however it is vital that everyone plays their part in helping ensure we avoid risking transmission of COVID-, by ensuring that you turn up at the airport wearing your face mask, maintaining social distancing and personal hygiene. We will continue to move in lockstep with Transport Scotland and adhere to Health Protection Scotland advice.“We do not know , or when, we will be able to travel as we did pre-coronavirus and given that all of us must adapt to these new habits and procedures in order to go about this part of our lives.“As we implement our procedures, we are doing our utmost to get everything right for our passengers. I would ask anyone who has any concerns or comments, to please let us know in the first instance so we can address them and contact a member of the team at your airport.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: kerbside recycling update from oic
story: vw, px"  Kerbside recycling collections are to continue with the current four-week cycle of single material types for households on the Orkney Mainland, Burray and South Ronaldsay.Councillor Andrew Drever, vice-chair of Orkney Islands Council’s development and infrastructure committee, said: “The system has worked well over the last three weeks. It has allowed the waste crews to collect recyclables that have been stored in folks’ houses, whilst ensuring that our crews are able to work within the requirements of physical distancing. To ensure we have cleared the backlog, we intend to continue with the four-week cycle again.”Green recycling bins and boxes should be put out on your usual bin day – but remember to do this weekly. You should remove the caddies inside # and the items for collection should be included in your single green bin or box as we will be unable to pick up more than one at a time.Grey bincollections for household waste will continue on a fortnightly basis – again on your usual collection day.This means that the council will collect:• Glass # week commencing June .• Plastic # bottles week commencing June .• Metals and tins # week commencing July .• Paper card # week commencing July .Councillor Drever added: “We want to thank households for their cooperation and patience whilst we continue to clear the backlog of recyclables that folk have been storing during the pandemic.”Just a reminder that paper and card is being collected this week . This should be contained in a single green bin or box. Corrugated cardboard should not be included – either in the bin or left alongside.It is hoped that corrugated cardboard can be accepted from next week at the recycling centres at Hatston and Garson, along with garden waste. More information about this will be provided soon.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. Reg No. – SC Registered Office: Hell’s Half Acre, Hatston, Kirkwall, Orkney, KW GJ

title: mcarthur close consultation required before any easing of travel restrictions
story: Clarity has been sought from the Scottish Government over the process for lting travel restrictions ahead of a possible reopening of the tourism sector next month.Yesterday, the tourism secretary, Fergus Ewing announced that the sector should prepare to reopen on July , subject to public health advice and progression to phase three of the route-map out of lockdown.But Orkney#s MSP Liam McArthur quizzed Mr Ewing on consultation procedures between island communities and the government around the lting of restrictions on ferry and air services.Mr Ewing confirmed that transport ministers are in regular contact with island authorities on the issue and are working with them to ensure the safety of residents and visitors.Following the exchange, Mr McArthur said: “Tourism is vital to Orkney’s economy and many local businesses have been severely impacted by the lockdown restrictions.#For them, yesterday’s announcement will have provided some ‘light at the end of the tunnel’.“However, with restrictions currently still in place on travel within Orkney, questions have understandably been raised locally about how this process will work in practice.“When publishing the transport transition plan last month, the transport secretary promised that any forthcoming decisions around easing of travel restrictions on ferry and air travel would be taken in close consultation with island authorities and communities.#That now needs to happen so that steps to restart the economy, which is needed, are taken sensitively and in line with public safety.“The tourism secretary accepted that point and I will be following up with his transport colleagues to get more detail about what this will mean in practice.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co.
